understanding.title: Understanding tuberculosis
understanding.subtitle: An infectious disease that requires attention
understanding.what_is_content: Tuberculosis is a disease caused by the bacterium called Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which after a latent phase, becomes active. This active form of the disease corresponds to a multiplication of the bacterium. It is accompanied by symptoms and requires prolonged treatment with specific antibiotics.
understanding.transmission_content: Tuberculosis is transmitted through the air by a person whose lungs are affected when they cough, sneeze, or speak. Transmission requires prolonged and close contact with a person who has contagious pulmonary tuberculosis.

itl.title: Latent Tuberculosis Infection (LTBI)
itl.what_is_content: In latent tuberculosis infection, the bacterium is neutralized, trapped thanks to the body's defenses. This bacterium can remain 'dormant'. The person may never develop the disease in their lifetime.
itl.active_char_5: Curative treatment for 6 months or more

symptoms.title: Symptoms and treatment
symptoms.treatment_content: Treatment requires taking several medications every day for several months. They must be taken on an empty stomach. In practice, they should be taken at least half an hour before eating.
symptoms.important_note: It is very important not to stop the treatment, otherwise the disease could return.

prevention.title: Prevention
prevention.vaccination_content: BCG vaccination remains strongly recommended, especially for children under five years old with risk factors.
prevention.screening_content: Tuberculosis control centers play a central role in prevention by organizing surveys and screenings around cases.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.a1: No, only pulmonary tuberculosis is contagious. When it affects other parts of the body, it is not contagious.
faq.q2: How long does the treatment last?
faq.a2: Treatment usually lasts 6 months, sometimes more depending on the case. It is crucial to follow it completely.
faq.a3: Yes, tuberculosis is very treatable today in France if the treatment is followed correctly.
faq.a4: Close contacts and people in frequent contact with a patient are screened by the tuberculosis control center teams.

q1.question: What causes tuberculosis?
q1.explanation: Tuberculosis is caused by a bacterium called Mycobacterium tuberculosis, also known as Koch's bacillus.

q2.question: How is tuberculosis transmitted?
q2.explanation: Tuberculosis is transmitted through the air when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or speaks, releasing droplets containing the bacterium.

q3.question: Which form of tuberculosis is contagious?
q3.explanation: Only pulmonary tuberculosis is contagious because it affects the lungs and allows airborne transmission.

q4.question: How long does tuberculosis treatment usually last?
q4.explanation: Tuberculosis treatment usually lasts 6 months, sometimes more depending on the case. It is crucial to follow it completely.

q5.question: What does LTBI mean?
q5.explanation: LTBI stands for Latent Tuberculosis Infection. This is when the bacterium is present but 'dormant', without symptoms or contagion.

q6.question: When should tuberculosis medications be taken?
q6.explanation: Tuberculosis medications should be taken on an empty stomach, at least 30 minutes before meals or 2 hours after.

q7.question: What is the main symptom of pulmonary tuberculosis?
q7.explanation: The main symptom of pulmonary tuberculosis is a persistent cough that lasts more than 3 weeks.

q8.question: What happens if treatment is stopped too early?
q8.explanation: Stopping treatment too early can lead to a relapse of the disease and the development of drug resistance.
